context: a sample note on bilateral myringotomy tubes
surgery which drains fluid involves a small incision in the eardrum, so that the fluid can be gently removed and a tube can be inserted.
surgery which drains fluid involves a small incision in the eardrum, so that the fluid can be gently removed and a tube can be inserted.

the need for the tube insertion is because the eardrum incision generally heals very rapidly (within a few days), which is not long enough for the swollen membranes in the middle ear to return to normal.

context: the need for the tube insertion is because the eardrum incision generally heals very rapidly (within a few days), which is not long enough for the swollen membranes in the middle ear to return to normal.
the procedure, medically termed a myringotomy and tubes, or tympanostomy and tubes, is performed on children under general anesthesia.
surgery is performed on an ambulatory or same day surgery basis.
within an hour or two after surgery, the child can be discharged home, to be followed up by a visit to the specialist in approximately one week.
within an hour or two after surgery, the child can be discharged home, to be followed up by a visit to the specialist in approximately one week.
they may have ear infections in the future, but most will clear up with medical treatment.
some children are very prone to ear infections and have a tendency to accumulate fluid after each infection.
occasionally the physician has to physically remove the tube from the ear drum.
